text:
ERIN CECH: Passion for
your job is everywhere.

It is in the way
that we are supposed

to think about the
work that we do,

what it means to
have a good job,

and at the end of the day,
how we are supposed to feel
about the jobs that we have.

The idea that
following your passion

is the best career decision
making guide seems obvious,

seems like it doesn't need
any kind of explanation.

But it's built on a lot of
false assumptions about the way
that the labor market works.

One of those false
assumptions is

that the labor market
is meritocratic,

that the people with the
most talent and skill

will always succeed,
and those who

are lacking in talent
and skill won't
succeed to the same extent.

But there's been a century of
social science research that

has demonstrated that the labor
market is not a meritocracy.

It is not a fair and
equal in that way.

There's not equality
in terms of who

is able to turn what they're
passionate about into a kind
of gainful employment.

One of the major
ways that people

are able to take the thing
that they're passionate about

and get a job in it,
and get a job that's

decently paying
and kind of secure,

is by relying on the resources
from the families in which they
came.

I talk about this as having
safety nets and springboards.

Safety nets are often
financial safety nets--

having a parent who is
able to pay for college.

So you don't amass a ton
of student loan debt,

or be able to
float you the money

while you take three months
after graduating college

to figure out what
your passion is about.

Springboards are
those connections

that you might have that
allow you to know somebody

in an industry that
you're passionate about
and get a leg up.

And that kind of
cultural capital

is really profoundly
important for being

able to launch into
a job that's not only

aligned with people's
passion, but has some element
of stability in it.

So take, for example,
two people who

are equally passionate
about computer programming.

And one person has
had the resources

to have been able to go
to camps about coding
since they were young.

And maybe they have an aunt
who is a computer programmer as

well, who tells that
person about how computer

programming is as a profession,
and what kinds of classes

you can expect, and
what kinds of skills

would be really
useful for that person

to be able to be successful
as a computer programmer.

And then you have
another person who

is really interested about
computer programming,

but has never done a line
of code in their life
before walking into college.

Those two individuals are
at profoundly different
starting points.

And so saying that
the second person, is

as long as they're
passionate about it,

they will be able to get
the skills is necessary,

really belies the
fact that these

could be years, if not
decades, of differences

that are really baked into the
structure of opportunities.

We know that people who
are going to put in 60, 70,

80 hours a week, but have had
advantages that allow them

to have a leg up, will have
a better opportunity to be

successful than
somebody that doesn't.

Employers really
like people who are
passionate about their work.

But they like it
because they believe

that people will put
more effort into the work

that they're doing,
without asking

for additional
compensation or asking

for recognition of the
passion that they put in.

People who are passionate
about their work

do tend to put in
more hours than people

who are less passionate about
the work that they're doing.

They're willing to
eat ramen noodles

for three nights a
week, as long as they
can do work that they love.

They're willing to forego
vacations or time with family,

or even starting
a family at all,

if that's something that
they're interested in,

in the pursuit of
work that they love.

And in trying to pursue
the work that they love,

they're putting in these
extraordinarily long hours

to be able to find and
secure and continue in work
that aligns with their passion.

We now exist in a
labor force that

doesn't deal with an
increase in the amount

of productive expectation
by hiring more people.

It just has greater expectation
of the people who are
in the jobs to do more work.

So that means that people
who are in professional jobs
are doing not 40 hours a week.

They're doing 60, 70, 80
hours a week in their one job.

Many of the people
I talked to said

that following your
passion wasn't irrational.

In fact, it was highly
rational, because it

was the only thing that would
allow some kind of insulation

from the drudgery that might
come along with working
for 60 years of your life.

But what that does
fundamentally is just

provide an individual
level solution

to what is fundamentally the
structural problems of the paid
workforce of paid employment.

We have to address
that structural problem

with structural solutions, how
we manage things like overtime

pay and managing the expectation
of overwork and work devotion.

The message is not that we
shouldn't enjoy the work

that we do, or that we
should all follow the money

and find work that's the most
well paying, the most stable

that we can, and disregard any
consideration of whether we

find work interesting
or meaningful.

One of the ways to deal with
the negative consequences

of the passion principle is to
try and shrink the footprint
of work in your life.

Regardless of whether you're
passionate about your job

or not, trying to make work
fit into a smaller time

frame in your life will
provide many more opportunities

for engaging in activities
that are meaningful to you
and are fulfilling to you.

One of the concerns
about centering your work

as a core part of
your identity is

that no amount of
passion for your job

is going to mean that an
employer is going to keep you

if that employer is
facing downsizing
or other constraints.

If we lose our job,
that can not only

feel like a change or a loss
in our economic security,

but a change or loss in
our sense of identity
and our sense of self.

One of the most important
things that we can do

is think about diversifying
our meaning making portfolio.

And what I mean by that is
finding activities outside

of our paid employment
that we find meaningful
and fulfilling to us.

That can be community
service activities,

some kind of intramural
sport, some kind

of artistic or
creative endeavor,

things that we personally
feel attached to
but isn't part of our job.

The idea of what it means to
make a good career decision

shouldn't only be about money
or only be about passion,

but rather should be a much
more holistic balance that

starts with the
question, what do

I want my relationship
to paid employment to be?
